title: Translating technical solutions into socio-technical possibilities: enabling technological transfer in the Bangladesh shipbreaking industry
abstractText:
Ship breaking on the beaches of South Asia, and particularly Bangladesh, is one of the most controversial of global recycling activiites. The controversies concern two issues: labour conditions in the breaking yards and environmental containment.

One policy response has been to rekindle the ship breaking industry in those parts of the world where it has long been moribund (eg the EU). A second has been to begin to explore the potential for technology transfer as a means to improved environmental containment and enhanced labour conditions.

This project takes the second response further. It takes a partnership approach to move identified transitional technical solutions further toward their potential uptake by market. A two-stage workshop is the principle means to progressing this aim. The workshops aim to:

  • Identify lessons learned from other transitional technological transfer projects in the sector.
  • To draw on these lessons, and from research conducted under The Waste of the World programme, to discuss the solutions identified within recent DEFRA-funded research, and to identify which solutions are socially as well as technically possible.
  • To enable and facilitate active discussion of these possibilities in Bangladesh.
